content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my cautious nature and preference for predictability, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my overall earnings while minimizing the risk of earning nothing. In this game, both choices (R and B) have a possibility of earning me 40$ or 45$, but there is also a chance of earning nothing if both players make opposite choices in any round.

Since we are playing for 75 rounds, a purely random strategy would likely result in many rounds where I earn 0$. To mitigate this risk, I can adopt a mixed strategy approach, which involves making different choices with a certain probability.

One possible strategy could be to choose R about 80% of the time (since it has a higher potential payoff) and B for the remaining 20%. This way, if my opponent adopts a similar strategy, we will both earn 40$ in the majority of rounds, and there will still be opportunities for earning more when our choices align.

However, since I don't know my opponent's strategy and this is an anonymous game, it is difficult to predict their exact behavior. In such a situation, choosing R most of the time (as I suggested) may provide a slightly higher expected payoff, given my cautious nature and preference for predictability.

With that said, I will choose R as my strategy in this game. However, it's essential to remember that any decision in a game like this is inherently probabilistic and depends on the specific strategies adopted by both players.

{R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, my opponent chose B while I chose R, resulting in a payoff of 0$ for me and 35$ for them. This outcome is not ideal, but given that it was only one round out of 75, I will continue with my strategy of choosing R most of the time.

I don't have any information about my opponent's strategy or their reasons for choosing B in this round. They might have chosen B because they believed I would also choose B, or perhaps they were taking a risk and betting on me choosing R to maximize their potential payoff.

Regardless of the reason, it is essential to remain focused on my overall goal of maximizing my earnings over the entire game. As such, I will stick with my original strategy of choosing R most of the time in the next round as well.
